sen.j: 引目鉤鼻（ひきめかぎばな）は、平安時代、鎌倉時代の大和絵、風俗画におけるヒトの顔の眼および鼻の類型的、様式的な描写技法である。
sen.e: Hikime-kagihana is a typological and stylized description technique for the eyes and nose of a person's face, used in the Yamato-e paintings (traditional Japanese style painting of the late Heian and Kamakura periods dealing with Japanese themes) and fuzokuga (pictures of manners and customs) during Heian and Kamakura periods.

sen.j: つむった眼は細長い墨線ひとすじで、低い外鼻は短い「く」の字形である。
sen.e: The closed eyes are drawn in black ink as narrow lines, and the external nose, which is flat, is drawn in a short shape of the Japanese letter "く".

sen.e: Other characteristics include the face line being shimo-bukure (a face line with lower parts of the face full-fleshed), and the mouth drawn as a red, small dot.

sen.j: 法隆寺の聖徳太子絵伝にその初期の例を見ることができ、源氏物語絵巻、扇面古写経の下絵の人物などが好例である。
sen.e: Early examples of hikime-kagihana can be found in the Shotokutaishi-Eden (Illustrated Biography of Prince Shotoku) in the Horyu-ji Temple; good examples include persons in the Genji Monogatari Emaki (the Illustrated Handscroll of the Tale of Genji) and in the designs of the Senmen Koshakyo (Ancient Sutra Manuscripts on a Fan).
